column19: We consider Digital Sustainability an umbrella term for two aspects: Sustainable Software and Sustainable by Software.  Sustainable Software concerns the sustainability of digital solutions in terms of their impact on environmental, economic, technical, social, and individual dimensions, including carbon footprint (Green IT) and process resources.  Sustainable by Software describes digital solutions designed to achieve positive sustainability impacts to help individuals and organizations reach sustainability goals, such as such as the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) more effectively.  Have you heard of this or a similar definition of digital sustainability before?

There are several reasons: Users and customers lack awareness of the potential benefits and value that sustainable digital solutions can offer, both in terms of impact (long-term, etc). The value of sustainable digital solutions extends far beyond reducing environmental impact — it contributes strategically to business performance, innovation, and social responsibility. There is a perception that sustainable solutions are expensive to develop.
Our customers are our students. They take the courses we offer.
column75: I have my own approaches for Requirements Engineering that include creative methods, checklists, inter- and intra relationship matrixes to study impact of sustainability-concerns on specification elements and SA modules, but I also use, for example, SusAF

column75: I lead the sustainability action at university, so we have done materiality analysis (EFRAG) and used autodiagnosis frameworks (CRUE and ETHOS). For teaching and tech projects: SusAF, ethical explorer, Critical systems Heuristics, Flourishing Business Canvas,  systems thinking (as an approach approach), etc

column31: I have been learning autonomously about the intersections of the digital, modernity and our general predicaments for the past ten years through conferences, books, people I have had collaborations with and so on. There have been no courses sufficient for the learning I have been drawn to.
column58: I would be the one to offer courses at the intersections of digital tech and the fundamental violations of natural principles that undergird it, and I would not have my courses build off of the problematic notion of "sustainable digital solutions"
column85: I am a researcher and educator, and these questions do not apply to me. Also,I reject the assumption that "digital sustainability" equates "sustainability".
